Thanks a lot to all of you who suggested projects. I have downloaded a
few smaller ones and will take on a few larger ones later (my modem
connection is a little slow for everything  beyond 2MB or so). As soon
as possible - but that may take some time - I'll build and test and
cover them :-)

Thanks also for the general remarks on coverage - I have had some
experience with this myself long ago, when I wrote a coverage
precompiler - source level - for C++ about 10 years ago and forced a
medium-sized project to go to 100% branch coverage. I also read Brian
Marick's book and a few of his articles back then. My raw gut feeling is
that there is more to code coverage than an arbitrary number ("85%"; or
"current level is 37%") and/or Marick's concept of "manual hot spot
detection" (if I remember it correctly; which is important!) and/or
impossible goals (the claim - also still mine - "only 100% feasible(!? -
how to determine?) is ok") and/or statistics showing how much/how little
correlation there is between some sort and level of code coverage and
functional correctness (does anyone know recent research/pracitcal
experience of such statistics - i.e., what is [some specific] coverage
"worth" on the "TCO curve of quality", so-to-speak?). 

Working in real teams with real time-pressure and real chaos and real
errors (also mine - I'm oftentimes a lazy guy who falls for "code first
and then dont test" the first moment I get under pressure ...), I'm
still (or again - after those 10 years) looking for the place where XP
and TDD concepts on the one hand; and code coverage on the other fall in
sync ... I also have a rough idea, but it's too early to talk about it -
I'll first try it out on my unsuspecting team ;-)

Regards
Harald
